Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SIMBUILDING: TEACHING BUILDING SCIENCE WITH SIMULATION GAMES

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is developing innovative simulation games for teaching and learning building science, integrating them into existing courses at Santa Fe Community College (SFCC), pilot testing them at SFCC and three other community colleges in New Mexico, and evaluating their educational effectiveness through tracking and analyzing learner data. The versatile and powerful simulation game engine, SimBuilding, being developed supports three types of simulation games in both English and Spanish: diagnostics games; construction games; and operation games. These different types of games will support both traditional students as well as building professionals seeking continuing education to improve their knowledge and skills. SimBuilding games allow for learner data to be automatically logged and analyzed to assist in understanding how students learn through the games. From this information, an intelligent tutoring system coaches the student as needed providing personalized learning. An independent consultant works with the project team on research and evaluation of the overall project and on determining the effect of the games on student learning. The SimBuilding games and associated curricular modules are being disseminated through community college faculty workshops, outreach to high school students and teachers, and at national building and green energy meetings and their websites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science concepts and technical skills in the building trade are challenging to teach at the community college level as they are often related to invisible and abstract processes such as heat transfer in complex structures such as buildings. But simulations provide an accessible approach to "make the black box" and make the learning process into a fun and immersive experience by using the principles of game-based learning.

In collaboration with Santa Fe Community College, this project has developed powerful simulation software for teaching and learning building science. These free and open-source software programs mimic how building energy professionals conduct diagnostics tasks to measure the energy efficiency of buildings with tools such as infrared cameras and data loggers and how engineers use simulation tools to design zero-energy buildings and renewable energy solutions. The simulation software also strive to deliver a game-like sense that entices students to explore in the virtual space and learn important concepts and skills related to the building energy careers. 

The software programs have been extensively tested with community college and high school students in New Mexico and received very positive feedback. Throughout the project years, the team has also built partnerships with leading companies to ensure that the skillsets supported by the simulation software align closely with the employable skills in the related technical fields.
